text: one of the main questions I get is often
well can you do x with evdf but what
about this and like what are the
limitations of evpf and actually it
doesn't matter that much because the
true power of ebpf is to glue existing
things together the example that Liz
mentioned is amazing there was a time
when user space TCP Stacks were becoming
more popular during the virtualization
age right because we have Frameworks
like dpdk and things like this that
offer better performance by going into
user Space by moving out of the kernel
because the kernel became so hard to
change and ebpf has now introduced a
tooling framework that allows us to glue
individual layers in the kernel and in
user space together and find more
efficient paths to connect dots of
existing functionalities such as the
well-proven TCP stack which has been
evolving for the last 30 plus years
right and it's probably the best TCP
implementation that is out there with
for example an Envoy proxy use running
in user space so it's less about solving
every single problem in ebpf that's not
the goal at all of the ebpf ecosystem
it's about we want to use the pieces
that we have that we want that are well
proven and working cut out the pieces
that maybe are no longer efficient or no
longer needed and find the best possible
shortest path for users to gain value
out of that so and that I think if we
look at this from this perspective it
actually becomes
